abstract.p: This paper describes how to use the machine translation system. It is a supplement to a master's thesis which goes into more detail on the background and documents a test case. Please see A Linguist-Friendly Machine Translation System for Low-Resource Languages.

p.comment: Ideas for content for this document
Sections to read in the thesis to get oriented. (temporary)
Installation
Sample projects, understanding, modifying.
How to ... FAQs
Things that were in the presentation to LSDev (variants [inflectional & normal],
Rule examples
Overview with diagram
How to edit using XXE
Each module explained
Configuration file
Troubleshooting

section1.p: The basic steps for machine translation with are as follows:

ol.li: Analyze the text you want to translate in the source project.
Link lexical senses that are in the source text to senses in the target FLEx project using the
Write transfer rules that convert source words and phrases to target words and phrases.
Run the six modules.

section1.p: Let's look at each step in more detail. For a more thorough treatment of each step see FLExTrans Steps in More Detail.

(It is assumed that you have gone through the download and installation steps as given on the FLExTrans Wiki and that you have FLExTrans working for the sample projects. It is also assumed that you have two FLEx projects to use as source and target projects for the following steps.)

ol.li: Create a new text in .
Paste in some text. (Start with a simple text; perhaps just one sentence.)

Analyze this text.
Divide each word into its morphemes.
Accept the analysis of each word.

section2.p: Word glosses, word categories and free translations are not necessary. A fully analyzed text will look something like below.
Note: Word gloss and category are hidden as well as free translation.

p.comment: Advanced info. for the later section:
All affixes and clitics need to have unique glosses
Use the parser for faster analysis.

ol.li:
Edit the configuration file and change two values.
Open Notepad
Select File > Open from the menu.
Navigate to the install folder and into the FlexTools folder.
Select FlexTrans.config
Change these two values:
ValueChange to
SourceTextNameThe title of the text you want to translate (from the source project)
TargetProjectThe name of your target project

Add two custom fields to your source project. This is where link information to the target senses is kept.
In your source project, go to the Lexicon area
From the menu select Tools > Configure > Custom Fields
Click Add and use the following settings:
Custom Field Name: Target Equivalent
You may choose a different names for the custom fields, but you also have to update the configuration file to match these names. The names Target Equivalent and Target Sense Number are already set in the configuration file that gets installed with .
Location: Sense
Type: Single-line Text
Writing Systems(s): First Analysis Writing System
Click Add again and use the following settings for a second custom field:
Custom Field Name: Target Sense Number
Location: Sense
Type: Single-line Text
Writing Systems(s): First Analysis Writing System
Click OK
Close the FLEx source and target projects.
Start in the installation folder. See for step-by-step instructions. It should look like .
Click on the button and choose your source database, i.e. project.
Click on the button which will bring up a list of collections as shown in .
Double-click on FLExTrans Sense Linker in the list and you'll see this:

Click on the button to run the module. Click OK on the message box that comes up to confirm you want to change data. You'll now see the with no links yet established. The window will look something like this:

Link each sense. (cf. )
For blue rows that look good, simply check the check box in the Link It column.
For red rows pick the appropriate target sense in the drop-down list, then double-click in the Target Head Word column for that row.
Click OK

p.comment: Advanced info. for the later section:
Explain why senses are linked. Bilingual dictionary, etc.

section2.p: If you have not yet installed and the needed files for editing transfer rules within it, follow the first two steps on this page. We are going to make a rule that removes affixes from words of a certain category. We'll modify an existing rule to do this.

ol.li: Navigate to the FlexTools\Output folder in your installation folder.
Double-click on the file transfer_rules.t1x which will open the file in . It should look something like . This is the transfer rules file that works with the sample projects.
Expand the rule element and also the action element so that it looks like .
Pick a category that you are going to process. In this example let's use noun, abbreviated "n".
Change the rule comment shown in blue to "Nouns"
Change the item element to "c_n". This means category noun. This changes the pattern to match nouns. Nouns get defined below.
Remove the two literal tag elements by clicking on the word "literal" and pressing the delete key. The rule should now look like .
Expand the Categories element and the second category element and it should look like .

Change "c_v" to "c_n" in the category element and "v" to "n" in both tags elements. Now it should look something like . Category "c_n" is now defined as the single tag "n" or the tag "n" followed by any other tag, i.e. affixes and the like.
Expand the Attributes element and the second attribute element and it should look like . Note that we already have a tag for a noun.
We are done editing the rule. You can save the file.

section2.p: In brief what this rule does is set up an action to take place when a word is processed by the Apertium engine that has the "n" tag. (Every word coming from has the word's gammatical category in the form of a tag.)

The action that gets executed is to basically strip off any affixes from the word. This is accomplished by outputting the word itself -- the "lem" part and the grammatical category -- anything that matches a tag specified by in the "a_gram_cat" attribute. No affixes are explicitly outputted. The target lang. attribute of the clip elements in above is selected so the target word that corresponds to the input source word is outputted.

The authoritative reference document for transfer rules is found in section 3.5 and appendix 3 of . intro info here (not sure if would be helpful) http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/Apertium_New_Language_Pair_HOWTO#Transfer_rules

p.comment: Maybe reference to where to find other transfer rules

ol.li:
Make sure you start the Apertium Virtual Machine. (See this link for instructions on setting it up.)
Start Virtual Box.
Click on the Apertium.
Click on the Start button.
In , click on the button.
Double-click on FLExTrans All Steps in the list and you'll see .
Click on the button to run all the modules. Click OK on the message box that comes up to confirm you want to change data. You'll see the modules run and see various bits of output.

section2.p: You can see the results by opening the target project. (You may have to do a "refresh" to see the new text.)

p.comment: Advanced info.:
Results can also be seen in the Output folder.

section1.p: The is a tool for linking source senses to target senses. The tool looks through the text specified in the configuration file and lists every sense that was analyzed in that text in order. Here's sample screen shot of the :
Here's a key to the color coding:

tr.td: Source sense has been linked to a target sense.
Source sense has not been linked to a target sense.
A target sense has been suggested for this source sense through a partial match of the glosses.
A target sense has been suggested for this source sense through an exact match of the glosses.
The target sense has been set or changed for this source sense.
There is a mismatch of grammatical category even though the glosses match.

section1.p: For suggested sense links (colored in blue), if you want to link them, simply check the check box in the Link It column. To link a source sense with a target sense where there is no suggestion or to change an existing link, you need to do two things. First, select the target sense that you want to link to in the drop down list of senses () then go to the Target Head Word column for the source sense in question and double-click there. The target sense information should appear with a green background color.
If you only want to see the senses that need to be linked, check the box that says Show Only Unlinked.

The is a tool that allows you to test source words or sentences live against transfer rules. This tool is especially helpful for finding out why transfer rules are doing what you expect them to do. You can zero in on the problem by selecting just one source word and applying the pertinent transfer rule. In this way you don't have to run the whole system against the whole text file and all transfer rules. Here's sample screen shot of the :

section2.p: Here's a quick guide on using the tool.

ol.li: First you want to choose something from your source text that you want to test. When you first run the tool, the words of the first sentence are shown both in the drop down list at the top and in the peach colored area. You can check one or more words and when you do the data stream format of the words is shown in the blue colored area. You can quickly select a whole sentence, by clicking on the Select Sentences tab and clicking the check box for the sentence you want.

Next select which rule or rules you want to run against the words you selected. Check the check boxes in the purple area as appropriate. Check them all with the Select All button. Uncheck them all with the Refresh button. Move a rule up or down by clicking on it and clicking the up or down arrow buttons.
Now you are ready to test. Click the Test button and the selected works will get processed. The results will show in data stream format in the green colored area.
Check the yellow Information box. It will show which words were matched for the rules that were executed.

section2.p: By default the transfer rules file, the bilingual lexicon file and the source text are loaded according to the configuration file. The transfer fules file and the bilingual lexicon file can be changed if desired by clicking the corresponding Browse buttons.
In this version of the tool, you can't change the Source Text Name. You will have to edit the configuration file, change the SourceTextName value and re-run the tool.

You may have noticed that there is a Manual Entry tab for the source text words. You can enter words (technically senses) directly in data stream format. This might be useful if you want to test a sense that isn't in your text.
The Interchunk and Postchunk tabs for the rules list are not currently available in this version. They are for use in testing the rules that are used in the advanced Apertium transfer engine.

You can't edit the transfer rules in the and even the change of the order of the rules in the tool does not get saved. Make your changes in a separate editor to reload the transfer rules after you have changed them, click on the Refresh button.
You need to have the Apertium virtual machine running in order for the to work.

ol.li: Navigate to the folder where you unzipped the install files.
Double-click on the file FlexTools.vbs (a Visual Basic script file)
The first time you run it, it may give you a message saying, "FLExTools has updated its configuration to match the new version of Fieldworks. Restarting."
The window should appear which will look something like .

section1.p: The Apertium data stream format consists of one or more lexical units. In , a lexical unit looks something like this:

types.comment: The following types are provided as pre-set examples. You may well want to create your own types that refer to one or more of these. You do that by typing in the names of the types in the types attribute of your type.
